title: Is it considered bad form to use a freely available font for a logo?
content:
I'm thinking about using Aller [Aller](http://web.archive.org/web/20100131091437/http:/www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/Aller) in a logo for a small company.

Is it considered bad form to use a freely available font for a logo?

I know very little about type, so I figured I'd come here to ask the experts. :o)
author: jkies00

comments.content:
@jkies00

Freely available or free? (Just asking.)  
But anyway, why on earth not?  
On my [blog](http://web.archive.org/web/20100131091437/http:/readableweb.com/) I'm using a free font for the logo type called "chunky".  
I find it delightfully ugly but that's my druthers.  
And it does double-duty at a much smaller size for column headings, too.  
In the midst of writing up a case study about the steps involved in choosing, deploying, etc...  
Please post about what you decide and where it ends up.

rich
You can assume a font with a free license might be found in the wild in more appropriate ways than other faces, but if it's an appropriate typeface for the project, then go for it.
thanks all. Richard, I'm familiar with Chunky, it is a great font. thx too aluminum. I'll keep Aller in the mix.

I agree with aluminium: Use it if it makes sense for the project. Don't, however, use it just because it's free. (Unless you're one of those GPL nuts, but that's another issue altogether.)

Even if it's a non-free font, you want your work to stand solid. As it so happens, Aller is a professionally designed font, sans-cost, that you shouldn't feel ashamed to use.
EDIT: meant to say "might be found in the wild in more \*in\*appropriate ways..."

There is always one thing one should consider (in my humble opinion):

Am I going to create a logo, and is that going to be it? In other words, will my customer get the logo, and be happy with it, and simply use it? If so, I can use ANY font I deem suitable!

however, should it be possible that my customer might one day use the font in the logo to do other stuff, like flyers, posters, or even use it as a textface.... then I would make sure I am using a font from a foundry that I can rely on to keep the font in good shape, and up-to-date. I would not use a free font.

I ran across the following problem quite a few times: there was a logo made with a free font, and all of a sudden my customer wants to use it for some big time advertisement campaign in all kinds of languages, including Cyrillic. The free font was good enough to do the logo - but you could not do decent print jobs with it, there was no OT version, and of course no Cyrillic version, either. They were quite angry with me when I told them. Shucks.

So if it is an artsy logo, which will end up being nothing but a cool logo, use everything you want! But if it is a business logo, and chances are your customer will get ideas, think twice before doing it. I, at least, learned the hard way :-)

I'd argue that (most of the time) one would not want the logo typeface (or logotype) to be used as standard headline/body type in the rest of the branding. You'd want the logo to stand out on its own.

Exceptions would be maybe something like the Walker, where the typeface \*is\* the overall branding element moreso than a specific logo. (But in those cases, you likely wouldn't be using a off-the-shelf commercial font--let alone a free font)

Free fonts typically won't hold up well for a high-exposure, iconic, branded logo.

But for lower profile, non-iconic logos that aren't seeking to develop a strong brand identity... yes.

I think it really comes down to branding. Most free fonts just can't hang when it comes to competitive branding. But there are exceptions.

It also depends a lot on what you do to the font to make your logo. Really strong logos most often don't depend ONLY on the font, but its smart usage including possibly, tweaking; just setting a word in a font, free or not, does not necessarily make the strongest logos.  
(Unless maybe if the font is custom and basically IS the brand.)

Following up on what Werfer said, it is important that if the type might break out for other purposes at a later date, the client needs to know that the lesser quality font they're considering won't withstand that. It's a dead end.  
The font i'm using on my blog is a complete dead end but it's not an issue.  
But for a company looking to use it to publish or whatever, they're in real trouble!
